original_title: Wii-Inspired Controller Built Using Raspberry Pi Pico
original_content:
We all thought Nintendo was going to change the world of gaming when it released the Wii all those years ago. In the end, it was interesting but not really fundamentally life-changing for most of us. In any case, [Sebastian] and [Gabriel] decided to build a Wii-like controller for their microcontroller class at Cornell.
The build uses a pair of Raspberry Pi Pico microcontrollers, communicating over HC-05 Bluetooth modules. One Pico acts as a controller akin to a Wiimote, while the other runs a basic game and displays it on a screen via VGA output. The controller senses motion thanks to a MPU6050 inertial measurement unit, combining both gyros and accelerometers in all three axes.
The duo demonstrate the hardware by using it as a pointer to play a simple Tic-Tac-Toe game. Its in no way going to light up the Steam charts, but the project page does go into plenty of useful detail on how everything was implemented. If you want to create your own motion gaming controller, you could do worse than reading up on their work.
Weve seen some other great examples of motion controls put to good use, like this VR bowling game. Video after the break.
title: Raspberry Pi Picoを使用したWii風コントローラーの作成方法
body: ニンテンドーがWiiをリリースしたとき、ゲーム界を変えると思われていましたが、実際にはそれほど私たちにとっては画期的なものではありませんでした。コーネル大学のマイクロコントローラークラスで[Wiiのようなコントローラー]を作ることにした[Sebastian]と[Gabriel]は、Raspberry Pi PicoとHC-05 Bluetoothモジュールを使用して構築しました。詳細はプロジェクトページで確認できます。
